Deus Ex Game of the Year was a genuine red pill that only boomer gamers speak of in reverence. The younger generation will never know the pleasure of receiving a sysnopsis of the secret struggle between dark occult societies. The makers of this game gave us a giant clue to the significance of its dystopian message - the conspicuous absence of the twin towers in the Battery Park scene during the early stages of the game - which was released in 2000. So how did they know the twin towers wouldn't be there in the future?

>A MANUFACTURED virus called the gray death takes out poor people
>Elites are offered a temporary antidote (Ambrosia) and effectively held to ransom
>Factions linked to the illuminati battle for world domination

posts.com:
Deus Ex is a fantastic game. I'm old enough that I played it when it came out, but I recently replayed it a few weeks ago. The story and detail of the conspiracies and a lot of the dialogue if you keep asking people is phenomenal.

The reason it predicted so much stuff is not because of predictive programming or the devs having secret knowledge, it's because they literally read conspiracy books of the time (stuff like Behold A Pale Horse had come out a few years before) and put everything in it.

The fact that conspiracy theorists are right about almost everything (as we've seen in the last 3 years) is why Deus Ex was so prophetic.

There is no way Deus Ex could be made now, there are too many people waking up to the truth. Back in the 90s these conspiracy theories were fringe knowledge known by crazies, whereas now we are in the ideological war stage and living in a dystopia of censorship and media control.

>Useful tips before posting:
•If you're a reader post that you're offering readings and what information is required from the querent; same goes for trading.
•Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader, what's needed and before posting, check if they finished reading already.
•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.

>>33715218
I'm pretty sure I died once. I was working construction briefly in my early 20's, and one day I was on some scaffolding. Anyway, some of the scaffolding was uneven and I tripped, falling off the side, approximately 30 feet towards a pile of breeze blocks collected in a pile on the ground below. The last thing I remember is putting my hands out and shutting my eyes closed just before I made impact with the ground. I kept my eyes closed, but this impact never came, so I opened my eyes and I was laying back down on the top level of the scaffolding again. Some of my work colleagues came over and asked me what happened, and I could only say I'm not sure. They later said I just tripped and fell, but just straight down, rather than over the edge as I remember. But this DID happen. I remember in that split second of falling, knowing I was about to smash into those breeze blocks face first and die. I remember the terror, the fear. I still had that fear even when I woke up and was OK. It actually affected me so greatly that I immediately quit construction as a career.

And yeah, I went over two sentences. Sue me.

posts.sub: What does X think of Nyla Nguyen and the 5d new age movement?
posts.com:
Nyla Nguyen on the surface appears to be yet another proponent of the global awakening movement. She covers everything from the prevalence of satanism, and kabbalah in the ruling class to the politics and dangers of the vax and global shifts in political power. It wouldn't be unfair to claim that she is in the same class as people like David Icke, Clif High, Max Igan, Jason Breshears, or Elena Danaan. All of whom claim to a certain extent that people are being influenced by outside forces that are not necessarily on the same plane of existence as the rest of mankind. There are some other consistencies between the stories of these individuals and many differences that could be rationalized as merely a difference in perspective on a subject none of them have a complete understanding.

She funds herself through an annual subscription to her videos on her personal website in addition to running ads for things like silver in the video description on various video hosting sites. Not necessarily unusual or particularly malicious in the context of the funding methods of countless other alt media outlets.

Broader questions to /x/ would be, is there any specific claims she's made that have damaged her credibility? Does she have known associations with what could be considered a handler in the intelligence community? Does she have any specific associations with anyone else in the 3D to 5D/ twin flame community? Has she made any specific predictions or statements that have been corroborated by others or that have ultimately come to pass that would reinforce her credibility? Are her funding methods tied to any known grifts?

Luffy is made of rubber to signify the ability to bounce back from any hardship with a strong enough thought/idea in your mind. This is willpower, it has the ability to aid in its holder's physical abilities as well. it goes by the name "haki" in the manga. From the beginning, Luffy always said that he is going to be the Pirate King. This is what he is directing his intent towards. This is where his thought energy flows, and this is the idea that the world molds itself to as a narrative.

Haki is specifically described in the fucking manga as this:

>"Haki" is a power that lies dormant in all the world's creatures... "Presence", "fighting spirit" and "intimidation"... It is not different from the things that humans can naturally sense such as these... 'The act of not doubting'. That is strength!

The act of not doubting... This is self-explanatory at this point. Belief is fundamental to changing reality. Look into Law of Assumption and basic principles of magic.
Faith, knowing, belief, these are what give the people the ability to perform superhuman feats in the One Piece world, as well as our world.

With armament haki, users can make their body and weapons harder than steel. With observation haki one can see into the fucking future (clairvoyance). With conqueror's haki one can knock out swathes of people just due to their overwhelming kingly/conquerors presence. Also, Reigen is the best and you will agree by the end of the show.

>>33746013
One Piece is literally an antidote to cynicism.
I used to work night shifts as a medic at a rehab. The kid who got me into One Piece saved my life and my soul. I had one patient who marathoned OP during his recovery and I wound up marathoning it with him.
The whole thing just RADIATES optimism harder than any other piece of media I have encountered. I was young and underpaid and working the graveyard shift.
This one patient of mine marathoned One Piece while I had him. His leg got busted up along with his addiction. We had him for longer. His leg was broken so I made him a splint and helped him walk again. The dealers had beaten him up and robbed him. I was a young medic working at a legally questionable rehab so all I could do was make him a splint and change his compression bandages each night.
All I was doing all night was responding to overdoses and suicides. This one kid who I had as a patient for like 3 weeks got to Enies Lobby with me while I just changed his bandages for a few weeks and stayed up late with him watching.
In all seriousness, the whole "DAIJOBU" that the 5th opening opens with kept me sane while I was responding to fucking suicides for 17 an hour. I know I'm not supposed to make friends with patients, but thanks, Josh. You dunno how much you helped me. I think you healed me and not the other way around.

I have one and I've never really seen anyone else talk about it. I think I brought this up on the chan once or twice long ago.

Anyways, during the Las Vegas shooting or right after it had happened, I was on YouTube looking at whatever. Randomly on my YouTube homepage there was a listing for some guy that was live streaming in Vegas so I decided to check it out and see what was going on.

The guy was going around to victims that were shot and basically filmed them and kind of played with their bodies. Nothing too crazy. Just kind of shaking them or moving them like he had never seen a dead person in real life and was mesmerized by it. A few times blood would poor out of their mouth and he would just go silent and sit there probably awestruck.

That reminds me. He was talking to these people he was recording too. He would go up to groups of people that were surrounding a person on the ground. They looked like they were going into shock because their mate or friend or whatever got hit. He would approach them and say "is he/she hit? I'm a ems tech. Show me where they are hit so I can help." And then he would proceed to do nothing or shake them like I previously mentioned. I remember him even doing it to single people that were in the process of dying. >>33740064
All this thing does is create a random number and slap it into a filename that has the structure used by default in a few different digital cameras.
Camera types and filename structure
"dcp#####.jpg" - Kodak, range of 0 to 4000
"dsc#####.jpg" - Nikon, range of 0 to 4000
"dscn####.jpg" - Nikon, range of 0 to 4000
"mvc-###.jpg" - Sony Mavica
"mvc#####.jpg" - Sony Mavica
"P101####.jpg" - Olympus, Using default camera date of 101
"PMDD####.jpg" - Olympus, M is in hex from 1 to c, DD is 01-31
"IMG_###.jpg" - Some other camera
"IMAG####.jpg" - RCA and Samsung
"1##-####.jpg" - Canon 1TH-TH## thousands, hundreds
"1##-####_IMG.jpg" - Alternate Canon name. MUCH thanks to Donald
"IMG_####.jpg" - Canon
"_MG_####.jpg" - Canon raw conversion. Thanks to Ira
"dscf####.jpg" - Fuji Finepix
"pdrm####.jpg" - Toshiba PDR
"IM######.jpg" - HP Photosmart
"EX######.jpg" - HP Photosmart timelapse?
"DC####S.jpg" - Kodak DC-40,50,120 S is (L)arge, (M)eduim, (S)mall. Thanks to Pholph
"pict####.jpg" - Minolta Dimage. Thanks to Bram
"P#######.JPG" - Kodak DC290. Thanks to Peter
"MMDD####.JPG" - Casio QV3000 and QV4000. Thanks to Fabian
"YYMDD###.JPG" - Casio QV7000 - M is hex. Thanks to Kimble
"IMGP####.JPG" - Pentax Optio S. Thanks to Matthew
"PANA####.JPG" - Panasonic video camera stills. Thanks to DeAnne
"IMG_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS.JPG" - HTC Desire Z (AKA Tmobile G2). Thanks to anonymously vociferous

> Please be careful though. this is basically a form of very random chaos magick, and what you find may be meaningful to you or fuck you up. happy randonauting!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well I'll just say this, if you really think about it the idea that "you only live once" is the more extraordinary claim.
It's really kind of odd how people take the more extraordinary idea to be the default, while they demand evidence for the more mundane claim.

The very idea of "only living once" is totally bizarre by any logical standard.
It violates statistics (if you only lived for a finite period within an infinite span of time, then the odds are statistically 0 that you would be observing it right now).
It violates every other notion of conservation.

Or to put it even more simply: You know you CAN exist because you do right now. But you DON'T know if it's possible for you to not exist... In fact the very idea is almost nonsense because if you didn't exist then how could you know what that meant?
So claiming that death is the end is to claim something can happen that you've never observed, and _by definition_ never can observe. Isn't that vastly more of a stretch of the imagination than to simply say that what already is continues to be (i.e. your existence)?

>>33749882
This is actually one of the only relieving things I've learned after realizing that reality is both infinite and inescapable, there is no chance of infinite hell. Yes, anything that can happen will happen, but that doesn't mean anything can happen for an infinite amount of time. The only constant is change. What goes up, most come down, and vice versa. It is possible that there can be a quadrillion year hell but, the moment whatever systems that are in place stop organizing that, it will change. The moment energy ceases to be expended on that, it will change. So yes, you can find yourself in a situation where there suffering beyond suffering for an unimaginable amount of time, but you can have the small comfort of knowing it can't be literally eternal. One additional but less solid comfort is the fact that you have agency, and this greatly increases your odds of being able to expedite your "escape" so to speak.

I suppose this comes with the major caveat that if you view reality itself as the hell (which is perfectly acceptable, and perhaps very sane even), then there is no escape. (You'll find these clever little paradoxes every time you consider infinity) Best to simply adjust your perspective on that one, because there's no-thing else for you.

I am not. Human persons are not just our souls, our bodies define us as much as our soul. Most powers of my soul are intimately connected to the powers of the body. For example, when I think, I must think in terms of mental representations of words, which we can only conceptualize through hearing. Hearing is a power of the soul which depends on the body (at least in man) to operate. Another example would be identity, could there be a more clear demarcation of personal identity that a face (body)? Both the soul and the body are crucial aspects of personal identity. Part of what drew me to the ideal of Christianity was that Christians have a better grasp of human nature than pagans, Buddhists, occultists, ect. We are not just our bodies, but we are also not just our souls. We have a tripartite nature of body, soul and spirit. In short we are ensouled bodies.

Until the resurrection we will be in a state of peace and communion with God and the saints (God willing), but this state will be one of incompletion, or a temporary amputation of sorts. To aspire to a bodiless state is to aspire to be an amputee, forever. For my soul to inhabit a different body would not only involve a state of incompleteness, but an unnatural blending of things which do not belong together (even more so in the case of animals). Both our disembodied souls and our disensouled bodies will be reunited on the resurrection of the dead. Our new bodies will be as a seed is to a fully grown plant, complete, and perfected. (1 Corinthians 35-41). How can God bring together the parts of a decomposed person into one new body? The answer is fairly simple, if God can speak the world into being, then he can command these bones to live, and live they will.

>>33742794
It would seem you would be indeed a quivk learner but also have difficulty with concentration and focus even when you know you should get to work on something and set yourself at the desk.

To better study, it would be good to, instead of procrastinating, integrate your personal research time and your study time and bounce back and forth. Trying to exclusively focus upon work for a session without the pressure of an imminent deadline may result in agitation to the point of abandoning studying altogether. So when studying alone, it might be good to spend 10 minutes on fun stuff, then switch to ten minutes of studying, then another break, etc.---making use of "breaks" but instead thinking of it as just doing both at the same time: multitasking.

You may also benefit from studying in a small group who have enough discipline not to let the study sessions get derailed.

>>33740539
That period of time, you may experience yourself feeling an odd, faint sense of melancholy. Ypu may dwell about problems occurring in your life and any that might be cropping up in the project. The mood may get depressive at times, but in that particular span of a few weeks or so that you've selected, you may feel a distinct motivation to push through no matter what.

You may experience it like the bounce of a ball. You fall and hit the ground, but immediately rise back up and continue going upward and onward.

You must be naturally adept at problem-solving, perhaps surprisingly anal and detail-oriented. You should have an affinity for the use of metrics and data. My recommendation would be to keep close tabs on the metrics of the development of your project and have a good sense of what anomalies are so that you can quickly formulate plans to squash them when they arise.

Also don't neglect self-care. Keep your office space very fresh and envigorating. Think about investing in scented candles or incense, noise-cancelling headphones with ocean waves ambience, plenty of coffee and water, a comfortable seat, well-ventilated workspace, and regular food.

If you have teammates you may be liable to rubbing them the wrong way or getting cross with them about something or other. Keeping yuorself personally pleased will allow you to keep work frustrations and life frustrations completely separate and allow you to better judge whatever conflicts arise in the workplace for what they are. People can be overly sensitive so you need to be prepared to be an adult and show them where they're wrong, responsibly.

posts.com: I'm not certain about the definition in a Christian context, but Aristotle used this concept a lot. Baiscally, prima materia is matter but abstract, because it has no form (i.e. essence, or specificities). It cannot exist by itself because it's only the second term in things (essence/substance). It's the passive principle which contains virtually every material possibility, but which has to be "opened up".

>>33723194
It depends on what you mean by "idea". From a platonic point of view ("platonic ideas"), essences exist by themselves, without their material manifestations: they are principles of the material realm. Aristotle was actually against Plato's doctrine of ideas, but still believed that essence were defined (though they didn't exist in the spiritual realm).If you want to understand this doctrine, I suggest you to read Plato's Phaedo. He never exposes this doctrine in full, but it sums it up. For example, beautiful material things are only beautiful as in so for ar they are linked to the Idea (Form/Essance) of Beauty.

The Prima Materia -is- the Quitessece/Aether, and is also connected to the Anima Mundi in western Christianity since the late middle ages.
By the way a 'Christian Hermeticism' as envisioned in that book does not exist, what does exist however is the influence Hermetism had on Christianity, during the middle ages saints like Albertus Magnus developed cosmologies based on their knowledge of arabic translations of hermetic texts (only the 'technical' kind dealing with alchemy, magic and astrology, the 'religious' kind both existed beforehand in Latin, the Ascelpius, and the Corpus Have got translated at the beginning of the Renaissance by Marsilio Ficino from Greek but it's influence never really went anywhere in the Church) and of neoplatonic ones, particularly the cosmology of Liber de Causis
Overall it's a good book, especially good as something introductory as it's a form of 'Catholic Sophiology' (Sophiology is an Eastern Orthodox movement) mixed in with more 'Occult' speech to get people who are into that get interested in becoming Catholic, but if you want to go deeper i suggest you delve into:
>Jakob Böhme (Protestant)
>Nicholas of Cusa (Catholic)
>Sergei Bulgakov (Orthodox)
And from there you can expand through studying their influences and who they influenced

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33727029
Sure,
Basically during medieval times the Aristotelian concept of the 5 elements mixed with the Neoplatonic Cosmogony and was used as the framework for why things like Astrology, Alchemy and Magic worked.
First of all Aristotle, basing himself on the philosophy that came before him, wrote that our world (planet earth) was composed of 4 Elements, but those 4 came from a single Element called Aether which Aristotle belived was the Element the 7 Classical Planets were made out of.
In Neoplatonism the Unknowable God, called One/Monad, emanates/'overflows' into Nous (meaning Intellect, but it has a more complex meaning) which you can interpret as the 'Knowable God', then the Anima Mundi (World Soul) and then from the Anima overflows material reality.
Now during medieval times those mixed together as material reality was belived to be composed of 4 unchanging elements, since the origin of our world originates from Anima Mundi that'd mean that the Anima is that 5th unchanging Element.

Like reading Genesis "in the beginning was the word"
What is "the word"? In Greek it was "logos". Logos can mean literal speech, like a proclamation. Or a language, maybe like computer code. Or an idea.
But it can also be a principle.

In Christianity there are a hierarchy of angels, which include principalities. The first act of creation was "Let there be light". It's a common belief that Angels are being of Light. However, before there was light there was "the word". A Primal somethingness. It was "with" God, implying "otherness" but it's not necessarily part of creation. So you can interpret that the prime material as the clay in which creation was shaped. Or that it's a thing outside and beyond creation.

In Alchemy, when you strip matter of it's qualities you're left with "salt" - a principle; not a cooking ingredient. I say all it's qualities, but it's still virtually "matter". The opposite of the "salt" principle was "niter". To understand niter you'll need to forget everything you learned in science. Because niter was an airy substance, but like salt, it was also striped qualities. Mind you, this is before they were thinking about atoms and particles.

If you could remove the matter-ness from "Salt", or the aerther-ness from "niter", the remainder would be Prima Material. It's something but nothing at the same time. A null value. The stuff that was "with" god. So in theory, if you stripped yourself all all your defining features, you'd be "with god" as well. Or at least closer to god.

>Wasn't that Satan though?

>Feel free to suggest resources
Resources:
Books:
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel
https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams
No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission. Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason
https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. Part grimoire, part reverence. Contains art and accounts by different people.

Videos:
Who is Lilith? Ancient Origins by Esoterica
https://youtu.be/n1EKccz4fS0
A fairly extensive history on her historical origins
The Untold Truth of Lilith by Grunge
https://youtu.be/01guwJbp_ug
A short video intended for a popular audience
Goes over her myth and general nature
Goddess Lilith - What she likes, how to contact
https://youtu.be/75bnMRPRiDk
A simple, short to the point video that rings true to my experiences.
My Experiences Workiing with Lilith
https://youtu.be/EHol9LrpWks
One woman's account of her experience

Well said.

>feminine sexuality and other weird stuff
For me it's been partially the opposite. Since working with her recently, I've been confronted with bisexual urges, and I'm still unsure how to reconcile them. It hasn't gotten to the point of feeling attracted to women in person, but nonetheless, my spiritual experiences lately have me questioning my sexual orientation.

It's embarrassing to admit, but I used to find women somewhat repulsive. I've always admired those who exemplify masculine virtues, and often saw women as the opposite, taking advantage of men's strength like parasites, subconsciously seducing their will just to satisfy their own needs. And I felt deeply ashamed of my sexuality as I recognised that same neediness within myself.

Even so, I still had to deal with gender dysphoria somehow. I already sought help from others when I was 14, but even then I could only wait as I lost things that felt important to me. But when I was 17, perhaps in a lapse of judgement, I turned to the occult. It was just a prayer to attempt to form a pact, and not even directed towards anyone in particular. But since then, my life began to change drastically, and I found relief that I didn't even think was possible.

As the wish I'd once made reached a satisfactory conclusion, and Lilith offered to guide me towards a new purpose, I thanked her and began to show my appreciation for her more. I thought I accepted myself now that I'm finally at peace with my body, only to feel lost again as spiritual experiences confront me with all sorts of sides of myself that I don't know how to reconcile. I'd have been content to ignore them for the rest of my life, but now I'm unsure how I'm supposed to proceed anymore. And although I recall her offer to guide me, I'm reluctant as I fear I'll be forced to face even more.

That's what I get for being dishonest with myself; for being so easily seduced as my contradictions are exposed.

>>33737944
I always struggled to relate to transgender people. Dysphoria was primarily a physical thing for me that ceased after my surgery, so I find the focus on stereotypes asinine and childish.

Two years ago, my older brother asked me to strangle his neck as hard as I can. He was curious if his neck muscles are stronger than my arms. I refused as it made me uncomfortable.
A year later, I felt scared as I realised how weak I am physically. But when I told my fiancé that I wanted to try building abs to boost my confidence, he was against it; he said he dislikes muscles on women. I lost motivation, as I realised I can never be as strong as him anyway.

I dislike alcohol, but knowing I'm way too hard on myself, I drank half a glass of champagne yesterday, hoping it would loosen me up a bit. The results were as agonising as I expected. It was far too little for me to lose control, but it became slightly harder for me to suppress my unwanted emotions. As they raged inside of me, I snuck away from my family and isolated myself. I forced myself to remain silent and still, but the storm inside only worsened.

When I returned, my brother noticed I was tense. He said to let out my anger by hugging him as hard as I can. So I embraced him, as if trying to crush him.
In that moment, I felt glad I'm physically weak. "I don't have to hold back. I don't have be afraid I'll hurt others, if this is all I can do", I thought.
But then, he said repeatedly: "You're strong. Those hormones didn't affect you nearly as badly as I thought." He sounded so relieved.

My brother is the strongest man I know. If I can be strong in his eyes even without training after 7 years of having less testosterone than most women, then I shouldn't belittle myself.
So I've decided to start working out and learn martial arts. It doesn't matter if I won't be as strong as I'd have been as a man; transitioning gave me other things that are more important to me. Even so, I still want to become my best self.

I attempted physical transmutation a few years ago, as I was curious whether it might work. However, I discontinued my efforts after a few weeks, as it caused severe inflammation and pieces of dead skin falling off in a particular area. Not only was the pain becoming unbearable, but I realised what I was doing was highly dangerous, as it was becoming difficult to even urinate. After discontinuing my magick, which consisted of daily energy work in a deep trance, the symptoms subsided in just a day.

My conclusions are that it's far more efficient to change physical things by physical means, and spiritual things by spiritual means. Not only that, but it's dangerous to attempt to remove body parts with magick; it's no different from convincing those parts of your body to destroy themselves, with no guarantee of actually getting the results you want. In my experience, physical surgery is both safer and much less painful in comparison. However, based on other results I got such as a sudden spurt of breast growth, I do think it can be useful for healing.

You posted here a while ago and clarified that you're not interested in physically transitioning, nor in changing spiritually. Perhaps it could be useful for you to try to understand why you think you want to be a biological woman, and find (other) positive ways for you to fulfil the underlying needs.

I thought of this one earlier but it's very trippy.

So when I imagine a picture of a brain I imagine it perfectly but can't draw it. I have a photographic memory, but my ability to translate this to paper is bad because of the way the brain needs to communicate with itself. The brain needs to take a mental image and then use a a linear thought process to control your hand into building the image it sees in it's head. It's your muscles, your thoughts patterns, your real time understanding of shading, space and color. All of this stuff is being processed in real time in a totally different way than you remember it.

The reason it's hard to reproduce perfect memories is because different parts of your brain have to reproduce the same image as the original memory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 17 year old Brianna Maitland was last seen leaving her job in March, 2004. Her car was discovered crashed into an abandoned building the next day, though there was no sign of her, and she has not been seen since.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In October, 1996, a woman calling herself Mary A. Anderson checked into a hotel in Seattle, Washington. Several days later, her body was found reclining on the bed in her hotel room, clutching a Bible (which was turned to Psalm 23 - "The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want."). She had committed suicide by cyanide poisoning. The name and address she used to check into the hotel turned out to be fake, and her true identity has never been determined.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Between February and October 1975, 7 women aged 16 to 22 were murdered by an unknown serial killer, with at least 4 more being raped. The survivors described the man as tall with large feet and hands (it is theorized he may have suffered from acromegaly), leading to him becoming known as the Bigfoot Killer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Voynich Manuscript is believed to have been written somewhere in Northern Italy during the 1400s. It apparently depicts several different subjects, such as biology, botany, and astronomy. It is written in an unknown language, very little of which has been deciphered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On February 10th, 2010, a man searching for cans found a black backpack containing a young woman's severed head. The head had been brutally damaged; so much so that police believe facial reconstructions may be unreliable. Her identity, as well as her cause of death (and whether she was even murdered) could never be determined.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Just weeks after the death of his mother, surveillance video shows 27 year old medical student Brian Shaffer entering a bar in Columbus Ohio. The bar closed just minutes later, and Shaffer was never seen again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Eight women were killed in Austin, Texas in the late 1880s by an unknown serial killer known as the Servant Girl Annihilator. The killer's identity, as well as his motives, were never determined.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Amber Room was a priceless, 590 sq foot room constructed from 13,000 lbs of amber. Previously located in St. Petersburg, it is believed to have been stolen by the Nazis after their invasion of the Soviet Union. Many people believe that it was destroyed in the bombing of Konigsberg, however, there is no proof of this, and its whereabouts (or that of its remains) are still a mystery.

posts.com: In 1943, a skeleton belonging to an unidentified female murder victim was found inside a tree in Worcestershire, England. Several months later, graffiti appeared nearby, asking, "Who put Bella down the Wych Elm?". This lead police to believe the victim's name may have been Bella. Despite this, her identity is still unknown, and her remains have since been lost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A family in Germany was found brutally murdered in their home in 1922. Before the murders, strange occurrences such as foot steps were noticed by the family, and a maid quit working at the home because she believed the house was haunted. The killer was never found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: For reasons unknown, 9 year old Asha Degree left her house during a thunderstorm on the night of February 14th, 2000, and began walking along a nearby highway. The next morning, she was reported missing, and to this day, no sign of her has ever been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Wow! Signal is an extremely powerful radio signal picked up in 1977. Its origin is unknown, however it is possible that it originated from somewhere near the constellation Sagittarius.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A couple of crazy guys from Brazil were found dead in 1966, but the cause of death has never been determined. No one knows exactly what they were doing when they died, but some believe they were attempting to communicate with aliens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The body of a woman (dubbed the "Isdal Woman") was found in a mountainous region of Norway in the early 1970s. She was last seen with two "menacing" looking men, who were never found. Her identity remains a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the early morning hours of March 18th, 1990, two men disguised as police officers convinced a security guard at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston to let them inside, under the guise of responding to a disturbance call in the museum's courtyard. The guard, along with the only other security guard on duty that night, were quickly handcuffed, bound, and locked in the museum's basement. The thieves then spent over an hour taking thirteen priceless works of art from the museum, including "The Concert", a painting by the Dutch artist Johannes Vermeer, which is considered by some to be the most valuable stolen object in the world. The thieves were never caught; however in 2013, the FBI announced that they knew the identities of the two criminals, but that they were already deceased. None of the art has ever been found, and no one was ever arrested.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 30 year old Kayelyn Louder disappeared near her apartment in Murray, Utah, on September 27th, 2014. She had made several strange 911 calls in the hours before her disappearance, claiming that someone had entered her apartment (her roommate, who was home at the time of one of the calls, claims that no one was inside and the door was locked). She was last seen on surveillance video with her dog near a creek, right outside her apartment building. Several months later, her body was found in a river about 5 miles from where she was last seen. The autopsy was inconclusive, and no one knows how she died.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On an icy Friday in January of 1956, six-year old Susan Cadieux was playing with her older brothers and a friend at a playground not far from her home in London, Ontario. At approximately 7:45 PM, a man approached Susan, and claimed that he had something to give her. He then told the other children that he was meeting with a priest at a church, and that he lived on York Street (although he pointed towards King Street). When Susan had not returned by 8 PM, her brothers told their parents, who then contacted police. By 1:30 AM, around 300 people had joined the search.
The following morning, at about 10 AM, Susan's body was found in a nearby warehouse. She had been sexually assaulted, and her cause of death was listed as exposure. It is believed she died less than 3 hours before being found.

Tears were frozen to her face.

Her killer was never apprehended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: At least 7 women were killed in the Connecticut River Valley area during the 1980s. The killer, who was never apprehended, has become known as the Connecticut River Valley Killer.

posts.com: In late 2015, a man on a camping trip discovered a moss-covered skull hidden under some vegetation in the Clocaenog Forest in Denbighshire, Wales. A nearly complete skeleton was found several meters away. Peter Moore, a noted serial killer from the area, claimed to know the identity of the victim, but this was later ruled out, and the Clocaenog Forest Man's identity is still unknown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On March 18th, 1967, the body of woman believed to be between 16 and 25 years old was found on the side of a road in Delaware. She was wearing only a pair of blue panties, and her body was partially covered by a canvas laundry bag. It was determined that she died of an infection, however her death was still treated as suspicious due to the conditions her body was found in. Her identity has never been determined, and she is known only as "Miss X".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 1999, a man named Ricky McCormick was found dead in a remote area of Missouri. In his pockets, police found two papers containing what appeared to be cryptic notes. They have never been deciphered, and the circumstances of McCormick's death remain a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Phaistos Disc is believed to have been created near the Greek island of Crete. Little is known beyond that, as the purpose of the disc, the meanings of the glyphs, and the date of creation are all mysteries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Investigators believe Jennifer Kesse was abducted outside her Orlando condominium on January 24th, 2006. Her car was later found at a nearby apartment complex. Security cameras at the complex took several pictures, 3 seconds apart, showing an unidentified person parking and walking away from her car. The person's face is obscured in all photos, and their identity, as well as Jennifer's whereabouts, remain a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A man identifying himself as Dan Cooper boarded a plane bound for Seattle in 1971, demanded $200,000 in cash, then parachuted out into a thunderstorm. He was never identified, and only a small amount of the money he stole was ever found.

I should point out that it was due to an mistake on the part of the media reporting this story that the criminal became known as "D.B. Cooper". The criminal never referred to himself by that name.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 2009, the body of a man calling himself Peter Bergmann was found naked on a beach in Ireland. Despite several months of research, the man's true identity was never found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 1984, a German man named Gunter Stoll, after showing signs of severe paranoia, screamed "Jetzt geht mir ein Licht auf!" ("Now I've got it!"), and wrote the letters YOGTZE on a piece of paper, then immediately scratched them out. He was later found naked after a car crash, claiming 4 men had been with him. He died on the way to the hospital, and the 4 men (if they even existed), were never found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the fall of 1982, seven people (three of whom shared the first name of "Mary") were killed after ingesting over-the-counter Tylenol that had been poisoned with potassium cyanide. It is believed that someone had discreetly replaced some of the pills inside the bottles while they were still on store shelves. The perpetrator was never caught.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mere minutes after this photo was taken, 3 year old William Tyrrell went outside to play in his foster grandmother's yard in New South Wales, Australia. He would never be seen again.
In April of 2022, his foster mother was charged with giving false information regarding his disappearance, however she was later found not guilty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Lisanne Froon and Kris Kremers were two young Dutch women who disappeared while hiking in Panama. Several months later, their bones were discovered, along with some of their belongings. Some strange photos were taken with their smartphones, and their call-logs suggested they were trying to contact help. A cause of death was never determined, although one forensic scientist noted that there were no scratches or marks of any kind on the bones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The ancient city of Teotihuacan, located in modern day Mexico, was once the largest city in the western hemisphere, with a population of at least 125,000. The native Aztecs who lived there, however, claimed they did not build it, and it was already in ruins when they arrived. To this day, no one knows who built the city of Teotihuacan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 1930s Cleveland, an unidentified serial killer horrifically murdered and dismembered at least 12 victims, most of whom were never identified.

posts.com: Béla Kiss was a serial killer who would place his victims in large metal drums containing alcohol. After serving in World War I, he escaped from a Serbian hospital, and was never found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Between 1971 and 1972, 6 young women were murdered in the Washington DC area by an unapprehended killer now known as the Freeway Phantom.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: No one knows why, when, or by whom the Long Man of Wilmington was created.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On June 10th, 1983, 25 year-old single mother Graceila Esquivel dropped her six year-old daughter off at Graceila's parents house. Esquivel claimed she was going out with some friends, and would return the following morning. However, when her parents returned to her home with her daughter, they found no sign of Graciela anywhere. Her drivers license and wallet were still inside, and the house was perfectly clean. She has never been seen since.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The day before her birthday in 2003, 4-year old Sofia Juarez disappeared outside of her home in Kennewick, Washington. Her disappearance was quickly reported to police, and within hours the local media, the FBI, and hundreds of volunteers were involved in the search. Despite this, no trace of her has ever been found, and no arrests have been made in relation to her disappearance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In late 1958, 5 people went missing while on a day trip near a river in Oregon. Two bodies were found several months later, 30 miles apart. The remaining 3 family members, as well as their car, have never been located.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On August 23rd, 1912, 4-year old Bobby Dunbar disappeared while fishing near a swamp in St. Landry Parish, Louisiana. Eight months later, William Cantwell Walters, a handyman, was arrested for his kidnapping. Walters, however, claimed the boy he had with him was not Bobby Dunbar, but actually Bruce Anderson, the son of a woman who worked for his (Walters') family. Still, the boy was returned to Lessie and Percy Dunbar (Bobby's parents), who claimed it was in fact their son. The boy would then spend the rest of his life as Bobby Dunbar, dying in 1966 in his late 50s. In 2004, DNA testing was done, which confirmed the worst: The boy who had returned and spent most of his life with the Dunbars was in fact, NOT Bobby Dunbar. The real Bobby Dunbar was never found. It is believed he may have drowned or been eaten by an alligator during the fishing trip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: From February to May 1946, the town of Texarkana, Texas was terrorized by an assailant whom the media dubbed the "Phantom Killer". The criminal claimed the lives of 5 people and injured several others, but to this day, has never been identified. Investigators refer to this series of killings as the Texarkana Moonlight Murders.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: This photo of Kyron Horman was taken on the morning of June 4th, 2010. Less than an hour later, he was reported missing, and has never been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: After having a picnic with several of their friends on a beach in Australia, two young girls wandered off and never returned. The next day, their murdered bodies were found buried in the sand. The killer was never found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Patricia Meehan crashed her car on the night of April 20th, 1989, after driving on the wrong side of the road. Immediately following the crash, she emerged from her car, and stared, motionless, for several minutes at the wreckage, before turning around and running into a field, never to be seen again. She was nearly 400 miles from her home, though neither the police nor her family could offer an explanation for this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Five men, all with mild psychiatric conditions, disappeared after attending a basketball game in Chico, California on the night of February 24, 1978. Several days later, their car was found abandoned in a remote area of Plumas National Forest, far out of their way back to their home city of Yuba, California. In June of the same year, after the snow had melted, four of the men's bodies were found. The remaining man, Gary Dale Mathias, has never been located. It has never been determined why the Yuba County Five decided to drive so far out of their way that fateful night over 40 years ago.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There was a serial killer in the UK during the 1960s that would murder prostitutes, then dump their naked bodies. The media started calling him Jack the Stripper. He was never caught.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Three children disappeared from a beach in Australia in 1966. The parents were not watching them, however this was considered normal, due to Australia being relatively crime-free at the time. They have never been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the early 1970s, three young girls were raped and murdered in Rochester, New York. Interestingly, all three of the victims' last names began with the same letter as their first names. Their killer(s) were never apprehended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: As many as 83 people, mostly Native American women, have been murdered or gone missing near Highway 16 in British Columbia, Canada. This has lead to the highway being nicknamed the Highway of Tears.

posts.com: After partying with his friends in 2008, 19 year old Brandon Swanson crashed his car in a rural area of Minnesota. While talking with his parents on the phone, he suddenly shouted "Oh, shit!", and was never seen or heard from again.

posts.com: In early January, 1935, a man checked into a Kansas City hotel under the name Roland T. Owen. 3 days later, after apparently being stabbed and strangled, he was dead. The man's mother claimed that she received some letters in the mail, supposedly from Artemus himself, including some after he had died. His killer(s) have never been identified.

posts.com: 6 people were killed between 1918 and 1919 in New Orleans by an assailant known only as the Axeman of New Orleans. In a famous letter supposedly written by the Axeman, he claimed to be demon rather than human, and very fond of jazz music. In the letter, the writer spoke of his plan to kill in the early morning of March 19th, 1919, but any house playing jazz music would be spared. No murders were committed that night.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In January of 1947, a young woman by the name of Elizabeth Short was found brutally murdered in Los Angeles. The 22 year old's body had been cleanly severed in half at the waist, and her intestines were neatly tucked under her backside. Her legs had been spread, her elbows bent upwards, and her hands positioned gracefully above her head, not unlike like those of a ballet dancer. Her face had been carved from the corners of her mouth, all the way up to her ears, forming a scar commonly known as a Glasgow smile. In the decades since, Short has become one of the most famous murder victims in American history. Her murder came less than a year after the release of a famous murder-mystery film starring Alan Ladd, which may well be how Short came to be known as the Black Dahlia. Her killer has never been identified.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One the eve of Christmas Eve in 1974, three young girls, aged 9, 14, and 17, disappeared after shopping at a mall in Fort Worth, Texas. A massive investigation was launched, which continued for decades, however no traces of the girls have ever been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Two girls, aged 12 and 15, left their Chicago home in December 1956 to go to a movie theater. Their bodies were found about a month later, though a cause of death could not be agreed upon. Some people claim to have seen them after the movie, though these claims have never been verified, and the murderer(s) have never been apprehended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Helen Brach was married to the owner of a large candy company, before she disappeared in 1977. Her chauffeur claimed that he picked her up at O'Hare Airport, although no one remembered seeing her on the plane ride there. No body was ever found, and no one was ever charged with any crimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the fall of 1982, 12 year old Johnny Gosch disappeared without a trace while delivering newspapers in his Iowa hometown. Over a decade later, his mother claims that she received a visit from Johnny in the middle of the night, while he was accompanied by an unknown man. Whether this visit actually occurred is debated. Johnny Gosch has never been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Before he disappeared, Matthew Weaver sent 2 distressed text messages to a girl that he had spent the previous night partying with. The next day, near the area where he was last seen, a person called 911, claiming to have heard a man and a woman screaming for help. Police searched the area, and found Weaver's car, abandoned, but no signs of life. These two text messages were the last anyone would ever hear from him.

posts.com: In 2004, Maura Murray withdrew about $300 from an ATM, then later crashed her car. She told a passerby that she did not need help, and that she had already called AAA (she did not). When the police arrived at the scene, she was gone, and was never seen again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 4 year old Michael Dunahee disappeared from a playground in Canada in 1991, just meters away from his parents. His disappearance resulted in one of the largest investigations in Canadian history, but he has never been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Capitol Hill's mystery soda machine was a Coke-themed vending machine in Capitol Hill, Seattle that was in operation from at least the early 1990s until its disappearance in 2018.It is unknown who stocked the machine.

A drink could be chosen using one of the "? mystery ?" buttons and the dispensed drinks were rare cans that were either ordinarily unavailable in the United States or had not been in circulation since the 1980s. Examples of the beverages were Mountain Dew White Out, a raspberry-flavored Nestea Brisk, a Hawaiian Punch, and a Grape Fanta. It was rumored that Vanilla Coke, Black Cherry Frescas, and Sunkist Cherry Limeade were also available. The owner of the business closest to the machine, a locksmith, claimed to have no knowledge of who operated it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Rebecca Coraim was last seen on a Disney Cruise ship where she worked. Security camera footage shows her having a seemingly stressful phone conversation with an unknown person. She then walks off camera, and is never seen again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: From the late 1970s until as recently as the early 1990s, as many as 11 women were murdered in a series of killings that is now known as the Redhead Murders. The killer(s), as well as many of the victims, have never been identified.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Starting in 1972, at least 7 young women were killed by an unknown assailant by various means, including strangulation and poisoning. The perpetrator(s) were never apprehended, though some believe the murders may have been the work of the Zodiac Killer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Three women, aged 18, 19, and 47, disappeared from a home in Springfield, Missouri at some point during the early morning hours of June 7th, 1992. Their house showed no signs of violence (except for a shattered glass lamp globe), their belongings were untouched, their cars were still in the driveway, and the family dog was inside the house, unharmed. No trace of the women has ever been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On December 13th, 2009, Steven Koecher parked his car outside of a retirement home in Henderson, Nevada, 150 miles from his own home in St. George, Utah. His reasons for being in Nevada have never been fully determined, and he has not been seen since. At the time of his disappearance, Koecher was behind on his rent. Several years later, his landlord was arrested on drug charges. Some believe that Koecher had been running drugs for his landlord, and was killed in a drug-deal gone wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 25 year old Tiffany Daniels disappeared near a beach in Pensacola, Florida in 2013. Despite several sightings, she has never been found. Her family believe she may have been the victim of human trafficking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In September 2013, unemployed drug addict Tiffany Whitton fled from a Wal-mart store after being accused of shoplifting, never to be seen again. Her case received significantly less media attention when compared to other young, white women who had disappeared, likely due to her troubled past and criminal lifestyle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On June 16th, 1990, 52 year old Trevaline Evans left a note on the door of the antique shop she owned which said "Back in 2 minutes". Over 30 years later, she still hasn't returned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 1912, eight people were found dead in a home in Iowa. They had all been brutally bludgeoned to death with an axe. Despite a long investigation with several suspects, no one was ever charged.

posts.com: Genghis Khan ruled what was once the largest empire in history. Before he died, he requested that he be buried in an unmarked grave. Several legends exist regarding his burial. Some say that several thousands of slaves and guards carried his casket to his final resting place, then were killed or committed suicide in order to hide the location. Others believe that a river was diverted over the ground where he was buried. Either way, almost 800 years later, the location of the tomb of Genghis Khan remains a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On February 28, 1983, a pair of looters entered an abandoned apartment building in St. Louis, Missouri. Upon lighting up a cigarette in the darkness, the two criminals were shocked to discover the headless body of a young girl, her hands bound with rope, and wearing only a yellow sweater.
To this day, St. Louis Jane Doe has not been identified. A crucial piece of evidence, the sweater she was found wearing, was lost after detectives mailed it to a psychic in Florida. The case has since gone cold.
Her head was never found.

posts.com: A Roman dodecahedron or Gallo-Roman dodecahedron is a small hollow object made of copper alloy which has been cast into a regular dodecahedral shape: twelve flat pentagonal faces, each face having a circular hole of varying diameter in the middle, the holes connecting to the hollow center. Roman dodecahedra date from the 2nd to 4th centuries AD and their purpose remains a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In 1984, a naked female torso was found floating in the Spokane River in Washington. The hands, feet, and head were all missing. 14 years later, a human skull was found at the bottom of an embankment, also in Spokane. It was later determined that the head belonged to the same woman as the torso found over a decade earlier. The woman's identity, and the identity of her killer, has never been determined.
After the head was found, detective Don Geise was assigned to transport it to a forensic anthropologist in western Washington. His fifth grade daughter, accompanying him on this trip, insisted that the unidentified woman needed a name. She decided upon the name "Millie", which is what the victim is still called to this day.

posts.com:
In Labette County, Kansas during the timespan of 1872-1873 a family of serial killers known as the Blood Benders (consisting of a father, mother, son and daughter) who spoke German, killed at least 20 people. They would lure people into the breakfast and bed inn, seat them at a table and have one of the men (who would be hiding behind a curtain) would hit them in the back of the head with a hammer. One of the women would then slit the throat for good measure and then dump the body in a nearby trapdoor.
After being questioned about the disappearance of a person who recently went in the direction of their inn, they quickly left with all of their food and personal belongings via their wagon.
They were tracked to the New Mexico Territory but were not pursued.
There are many stories about what happened to them and even some arrests of the women, but many doubt the authenticity of the stories and the identity of those arrested.

>>33744163
Look up the case of Christopher Knight, AKA 'the North Pond Hermit.' He lived innawoods for 25 years before being caught. He was up on charges of stealing since he'd steal the bare minimum of the bare essentials from nearby homes and homesteads. You may want to learn from his mistakes and mimick his successes.

A few things to consider:
1. Knight never lit a fire. This helped him escape detection.
2. Beware of thermal camera drones, I wouldn't be surprised if civilian ones are used to track down isolated camps on public land. Hadjis in the middle east combated these with thick wool blankets.
3. Read books on survivalism and watch YouTube about it. Understand what you're taking on and whether being homeless in a big city, with all its attendant dangers and degradations, might not be a safer option for you.
4. At minimum get yourself a long-life portable water filter such as a katadyn. Splash out here if nowhere else. Water borne disease will rape you dead.
5. You may want to have a portable camp or multiple spots you move between in an irregular fashion.
6. If you're going to plant forest gardens be prepared to defend them from wildlife, especially deer. They are bad enough for settled farmers much less hermits and will destroy an entire acre of crops in a night, if not more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33750269
Of course not. We're (biology) just the most recent expression of the universe's nature, that of emergent order. It's an unresolved process and we're the next layer of the reaction. The point is, our minds are inherently rooted in the material nature of the universe. By definition, everything we are is a SOMETHING. There's no way to have any practical experience with nothing, because to have that experience you'd have to be nothing too, and then there would be no brain to store and consider the information about it. Worse still, there would be no information TO store or consider.

Nothing as a broad philosophical concept, is like trying to wrap your mind around infinity. You can't in any intuitive way. It just throws computer errors between your ears. We can only attempt to describe these concepts according to limited local observations which, again, by definition, are inherently and inevitably flawed methods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33750342
2 + 2 is impossible in reality. There is not any item for you to consider that is perfectly equivalent to the next. Just close enough to be categorized or considered in a way that we find useful. There isn't a single item to consider, measure, or otherwise interact with that we have pinned down in a perfectly 100% accurate way. The answer to all questions are fundamentally infinite and therefore unknowable in their entirety. You can make no predictions that there will not eventually be exceptions to, therefore there are no perfect rules (with only the infinite exceptions, which paradoxically reinforces the point). Now, I understand for our purposes that we can agree that anything that can be sensed or considered is a "thing", that's fine, but I'm not compelled to believe that the laws of reality acknowledge this distinction. It must be so, or this state of affairs should not be as it is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It really depends on who you are.

Some people are born or raised in such a way that they have a clean mind and few psychological problems. For them it's easy to focus and direct their mind.

Others (like how I used to be) literally live in their mind all day long, they daydream a lot and their thoughts literally control their actions and how they feel, and the worst is that they don't even realize it because they've been living like this for so long.

So I'd suggest that you just sit and observe, just sit and don't chase anything because you may be just chasing goals which are not achievable or you might be running away from harsh truths which you must first face and endure before you can move on to greater things.

Your mind is NOT you, this was a hard pill for me to take, all those thoughts which sound 100% true are just fabrications of a wild mind.

So yeah, just sit and watch, watch how your mind goes running around but don't follow it, nor make stories about it, don't try anything for there is nothing to try, just sit, your mind will come up with all crazy stuff and you will just sit there and watch it BUT without thinking "Oh I'm watching now, I'm meditating so good" for that is also thinking.

Just be the observer, and yes, with time your mind will calm down and you will be left alone or with very few thoughts, then the real "You" will start becoming clearer and that's when you can direct your focus on APing, chakras/whatever, subconscious, old forgotten memories and other things.
But you gotta first sit in silence, sit without trying to do anything. Just observe.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33705047
sit down.
close eyes (personally recommended)
Place tongue gently on roof of mouth.
Focus on the breath going in and out of your nose.
If any kind of sensation/thought/distraction comes up, note it with a simple label (whatever comes first/is natural) and gently return back to the breath.
Don't control anything, just watch your breath going in and out like you were cloud watching.

posts.com:
I've been meditating for years now and yet I can't really put into words what meditation is, I like the "meditation is deliberate focus of awareness" thing that people usually talk about.

Cultivating the ability to focus takes time. Focusing on the breath or a candle are the 2 basic exercises people recommend, it teaches you to "feel" and "observe" which are different from "thinking", it may take months to snap out of the "thinking" mode for just a second but that sole second is enough to show you that your thinking mind is not you nor your reality, it's like a radio which plays all the time and you were living with that radio open for most of your life.

>>33699233
For me the "observer" focus/mode is when you are not a slave to your thoughts and you are calmer thus you don't get dragged away by them, while the "focus" focus is the ability to focus on one thing with all your might, I say that those 2 go hand-in-hand and maybe someone could say that they are the same thing: the ability to take a step back from everything, be calm and direct your focus/observing whatever you want.

Also during my sits I remember how to feel my feelings. Feelings inhabit your body and you can feel them better if you focus on them, they usually carry forgotten memories or various insights and blissful states if you focus on them enough.

Meditation is a paradox to me, it's like a means to an end but also the end itself, it's like a vehicle which takes you places but also it's just erasing all the unnecessary noise around you to realize that all those places were always here next to you.

So sit and watch your breath, feel your body breathing, your mind will make thousands of stories about anything but just let it be, don't even label those thoughts, don't even say "I'm letting them go", just let them be and focus on your breath, on the feeling of your body breathing, your mind will say "that's stupid, analyzing these important things is better", but just focus on the breath.

>>33710828
What you say makes sense but from my own experiences I 'd say that those 2 are the same thing.

Focusing is like an ability, people are good at it or not.

You can be focused on just this moment and your surroundings without being focused on a single object. This is like being totally present, you are focused on the present, your mind isn't wandering outside of your control, thoughts may pop up but they don't take you away in daydreaming (which most people have but don't realize). Imagine that this focusing ability is like a magnifying glass, let's say that what I just described is the point "zero" of the magnifying glass, our basic reality. This is what you called the "observer" mode.

However you can zoom into one single thing using that magnifying glass, say your breath or an object. You can literally move your entire consciousness towards that thing to the point that your awareness travels there, some people say that "wizards/shamans/yogis" can move their entire consciousness towards that object and move it with their will or inhabit the body of an animal, others say that they can zoom their eyesight so much to the point that they look at the atoms of an object, some even say that they hypnotize others through this way. This is the point "1" of the glass.

Conversely you can even zoom out, you can become the whole room and even look at yourself from above, you can become your whole house and the whole city, you can focus on the whole galaxy and the whole cosmos, you can even break the linear time illusion and realize that everything is one single moment which takes place here and now. Let's say that this is the point "-1" of the glass.

That's what meditation is: Realizing that you are everything at the same time, your awareness can go everywhere since you are part of the whole, the ego is an illusion, break free from it and realize that you are whole, ignore your thoughts which most of the time are just the ego talking nonsense.

>>33699233
This post made me want to share something semi-related - an experience of mine:

For years I always wondered if non-directive meditation is the same as directive meditation, or if one was better than the other or even the "correct way to meditate".

In the non-directive kind you just sit and be aware, if something pops up you just watch it until it goes away without making stories in your mind about it.

In the directive aka focus meditation you focus on a single object and you stay with it, if something else pops up you immediately return to the object.

After practicing both for a long time I can say one thing: They both have the same result which is your thinking mind eventually quieting down, the thoughts become less and less and you are left in silence and that's when the real fun begins.

(continued in the next post)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33726002
(cont.)

I could say that non-directive would be better suited for advanced practitioners who can manage their thoughts better and are better at not being dragged away from their wandering mind, those are the practitioners who are more grounded, whose their breath is 24/7 calm. That's the "observer focus" you are talking about.

Directive is better for people who are new to meditation, those people are usually overthinkers, their breath patterns are all over the place, I'd suggest that someone who begins meditation focuses on his belly expanding or his chest or on the feeling the air makes in his throat. I suggest this because in an overthinking beginner the thoughts are coming at a very fast and strong rate. Imagine this kind of meditation like you holding on a steel pole with all your might so the tornado (thoughts) won't drag you away. That's the "focusing focus" you talked about.

So it all comes down to having a calm mind, and sitting will do this anyway, sit in the dark with no sound or anything to bother you and the thoughts WILL stop, what really helps is if you also incorporate breathwork and physical exercise in your everyday life and if you reduce screen usage (which fills your mind with lots of information), these will help you reach the "no-thought" state faster.

I remember sitting down to do "Focus on breath" meditation and various memories and bad feelings popped up, I ignored them and returned to the breath, then thoughts like "You are ignoring what's important!" popped up and I became anxious that I was using meditation to run away from my problems but I knew that I wasn't really doing that and that was just my overthinking mind not wanting to stop. Most of our problems are just thoughts in our minds and are not real at all.

So just sit and focus on the breath or on the moment, or on your body, don't think too much about it, thoughts and words are not everything, feeling is also important, feeling this moment here now.

>>33700019
Start with objects that are in another room from where you are. Then move on to physical settings in the house, imagine whole rooms and whole layouts of the house. Next, move to things that are outdoors like a park, a lake, forest or other natural settings of the sort. After that move to more dynamic situations like a busy city center, a school campus between classes when there's a lot of people walking everywhere, a busy restaurant, etc. After than imagine scenarios with yourself and other people who are immediately with you where you give each person unique physical attributes, personality traits and have them say the certain things you want them to say.

Literally that simple. Should take you sometime.

>>33732995
Shut off your PC monitor, close your laptop, back away from the desk.

Sit up right but remain in a relaxed position. Close your eyes. Take a deep breath through your nose and feel as the air travels down through your lungs and you expand your belly to fullness. Holy for 3 seconds, then slowly exhale through your pursed lips. Repeat twice more. Feel relaxed and just let your thoughts flow. Don't get in their way, just let them happen, sit back and observe. Keep breathing normally through your nose and continue to let your thoughts happen, sit back and observe them. Do this for the next 5 minutes.

There. You've done mindfulness meditation and you are going to feel better after the 5 minutes are up. Do this for the next few weeks and write down any worries, anxieties, intrusive thoughts, or recurring themes that run through your mind while meditating.

That's literally all you have to know right now. Meditation is one of those things that are better of just experiencing from the get got instead of reading about them. You can do body scan meditations, mantra meditations, visualization meditation and KUNDALINI BRO later. No need to complicate things.

Keep reading and lurking the thread for resources.

>>33744644
I'm the same anon who said that quitting coffee helps, I'm here with new things you can consider:

- Maybe your volition is not that strong? Maybe you just sit and you hope that something happens? Maybe instead of trying to focus on your breath you half-ass it and your mind takes you over all the time? You have taken notice that you are indeed mind wandering, you have taken the first step of observing this - a step which many humans never take in their whole life - so why you don't act? Why your mind keeps on being the leader?

- Maybe your thoughts seem like they are extremely important and you can't ignore them? If yes then write them down after each session and really ask yourself: Is this important now? Most of the time it isn't, it's most likely a past semi-traumatic event which keeps on repeating in your head, or a worry about the future, ignore them both, the now is the most important thing.

- Maybe you are trying to focus on your breath through your thinking mind? That's too narrow, try to FEEL, like literally feel your whole body breathing, the breath fills your lungs only but it also moves your belly and your pelvic floor with its movements, your shoulder blades and clavicle may also move during inhalation/exhalation, feel your whole body sitting there and breathing.

- Speaking of the body, try to keep your head retracted (search about this head posture), also imagine a thread which is attached in the middle of your head pulling it lightly up, this head position helps with sleepiness.

- Again: Don't make a story about it, it's just you breathing, yes you will just sit there and feel yourself breathing, your mind will think "What? Only that? That's too simple/stupid/whatever", but believe me: first achieving calmness and silence is the most important thing.

- And last: Coffee is not the only thing which may hinder your meditation practice, everyday cannabis smoking or regular pills may hinder it too.

>>33744644
Everyone is saying that you should focus on your breath and maybe it works for some people but I will speak about my own experience: I was trying for years to concentrate just like you and I just couldn't, then I decided to just sit and accept in silence without trying to fight or force anything nor direct my focus 100% on something, just observe myself in silence.

I did that because I knew that I had unresolved childhood trauma inside of me, I was full of anger and anxiety most of the day and even during meditation, it was like a huge alarm which was ringing for years now and I wasn't doing anything about it.

This way of meditating did indeed have some kind of focus but it was more of a calm, "sit back and relax" kind of focus in which I was just being aware of everything that came, some people call this "transcendental meditation" or "mindfulness" I think.

So you could say that my object of meditation was my thoughts which were usually various past experiences which I had the tendency to remember all the time or even made-up scenarios. Nearly all of those thoughts carried hateful feelings with them and my mind wanted to live out those scenarios which they usually ended up in me beating up someone who had mistreated me, I had violence and hate inside of me (all from my abusive childhood).

However as I said before in my meditations I didn't sit to fight or force things but I sought to observe in silence, so every time this pull came, this pull towards violence - this pull towards making more thoughts and extending the scenario - I choose instead to just sit, and what I saw was fear that the other person was mistreating me and I wasn't doing anything, this feeling of fear was so strong which was almost unbearable and it took me many meditations to finally resolve it.

So as >>33744852 said, yeah I was probably using meditation as a way to escape those alarming feelings of hate and fear.

Maybe something similar is happening to you? Who knows.

>Examining European modern humans in regards to the Altai Neanderthal genome in high-coverage, results show that Neanderthal admixture is associated with several changes in cranium and underlying brain morphology, suggesting changes in neurological function through Neanderthal-derived genetic variation. Neanderthal admixture is associated with an expansion of the posterolateral area of the modern human skull, extending from the occipital and inferior parietal bones to bilateral temporal locales. In regards to modern human brain morphology, Neanderthal admixture is positively correlated with an increase in sulcal depth for the right intraparietal sulcus and an increase in cortical complexity for the early visual cortex of the left hemisphere. Neanderthal admixture is also positively correlated with an increase in white and gray matter volume localized to the right parietal region adjacent to the right intraparietal sulcus. In the area overlapping the primary visual cortex gyrification in the left hemisphere, Neanderthal admixture is positively correlated with gray matter volume

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33748589
yeah, this. also, each day/month/year is continually growing shorter in relation to your total time spent on this earth.
one year for a two year old is 50% of their life, but one year for a twenty year old is 5% of their life.
let yourself be bored more often, or do things that move you away from your routine.
if you do the same thing every day, then it's obvious that at some point they'll melt together and an entire year can feel like one very long, blurry day.
you don't have to adopt the "yolo live every day like its your last" mindset and go to the extremes of literally living each day differently, but you could break your time into chunks, if that makes sense.
so, for me, something that helps me "slow down" my clock is by breaking things up into the seasons. in the spring, i spend a lot of time preparing my garden.
during summer, i spend a lot of time outside both enjoying my garden and tending to it. i also spend a lot of time 'experiencing the world' by going camping, on bike rides, walks at night
in the autumn, i start to harvest the majority of what i've planted (lots of smaller things get harvested throughout the year), then i start cleaning everything and putting it into compost.
then, i use winter as a time to hunker down and reflect.

basically, enrich your life with more variety but also give yourself time to be bored and do nothing. then you'll actually enjoy the mundane and it won't morph itself into some weird caricature.

No and Yes.
Time is a subjective construct, time is moving faster to you because as you age what once was a long time feels much shorter. On the otherhand the physical concept of time as it relates to the earth is actually speeding up due to the fact that our earth is continuously spinning on its axis, and this rotation is continuing to accelerate every second. Gravity affects this too, technically the further you are from the earths surface the faster time will run, but the change is so incredibly small it is unnoticeable.
